page.lettertext:
fol.266r
Belgia 1590
Belgia 23 Au
g
1590 of dunkerck
bis
May it please yo
r
good L. w
t
in these three
daies there came
one
unto me, whiche was pensioner,
nine yeres past, in
e towne of
Dunkerke
: a man
unknowen to my self, but esteemed of others very
honest and religious, and qualified besides, for
other good partes. Sins his comming out of
Dunkerke, his chiefest aboade, w
t
his wife and
familie, was first in these quarters, and after-
wardes in
Dantzicke
: from whens he returned
about nine monethes sins, and keepeth nowe at
the
Hage
: having competent meanes to main-
tene his estate. The cause of his com-
ming unto me, was to lett me understand,
that if her
Hig
nes
were desirous, to surprise
the towne of Dunkerke, he would disclose unto
me an easie, and a readie meanes, and suche
as her Ma
tie
w
t
a very smalle charge, might
put in execution. He desired only to have
it secretly caried, and if her Hig
nes
shall re-
fuse to deale in
e action, that then it may
remaine, and not be notified to others. For
e
atchieving of
e enterprise, is would be requi-
sit, uppon pretense given out, ether of sending
more assistance into these contreis, or of
e like
attempt, to embarke at
Dover
, or some other
part there adjoining, to
e number of 1400 men,
or thereabout. Whiche are to be landed by
night w
t
shalloppes, in two several places neere
the towne: to witte a fiveth part of
e number,
or so many more or fewer as shalbe thought ex-
pedient, neere unto
e way that leadeth from
ostend
and
Nieuport
, to
e Est gate of
e towne:
fol.266v
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
:
and the rest at
e Downes, whiche are opposit to
e
North
west
port. W
t
good circumspection, and a fitte
opportunitie of tide and winde, it may be done very
safely in bothe places, so as by night they shall not
be descried, by
e watche of
e Estbulwarke.
The lesser number being landed, whiche they maye
easely doe, as neere
e towne, as they list, they
are to marche directly in
e forsaid way, whiche
is gravely and good, towardes
e Northest tower,
for w
ch
they shall have guides assigned, and about
e distance of 5 or 6 passes from
at tower, they
shall finde
e towne dicke but 3 foote deepe, so
as they may passe it, and make an assault, at
e same instant as
e rest of
e souldiers, shall
enter
e North
west
gate of
e towne: whereto they shall
be conducted, by skilfull persons, thorowe
e downes;
having nothing to stoppe them from approching
e
gate, but a chanel of 30 or 40 passes, w
ch
is
drie in a lowe water: having only in
e middle,
where there is, for almost 5 yardes breadth, be-
tween 2 and 3 foote depth of mudde: whiche
inconvenience may be quickly holpen w
t
2 or
3 strong hurdles. The port itself is made
in
e forme of a lattise, or grate, w
t
two leaves, or
half partes, whiche are shutte
a crosse
, w
t
an iron chaine,
not three inches thicke, and come not so neere,
but that a man w
t
ease may enter between: besides
that
e chaine may be soone broken, both it and
e
gate being rusty and old. Moreover five or
six passes w
t
in
e gate, there is a faire stone paire
of staires, sufficient large, for two men to mount
in a front, whiche bringeth directly to
e standing
fol.267r
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
watche, on
e market place: and from thens there
is a plaine way to
e towne house, where there is
also an other
corps de garde
, whiche having bin
dealt w
t
all,
e Estgate being neere at hand, may
be easely seased, and entrance made for
e rest
w
t
out. The successe wherof, and of all
e exploit
is
e lesse to be douted, for
at there are not in
the towne, as we are informed, above 300 souldiers
in Garrison: and
e burgers all unarmed, and
desirous of libertie, and trafficke. Also,
to
e end her Ma
tie
may be throughly assured, that
not only the meanes, to perfourme this action, are
suche as he proposeth, but that his meaning is cleere,
and syncere, and voide of all occasion, that may
minister suspition, he declareth unto me, that there
is no man privy to this ouverture, but one only
gentleman in
Flushing
, whiche hath borne sometime
the office of an Eschevin in Dunkerke, a man of
good credit, and courage, and zelous in religion.
And in case her Hig
nes
be resolved to embrace
e
enterprise, and shall finde it expedient in respect
of further conference, and more assurance, that
one of them bothe, or bothe together, should come
into
England
, they are willing to doe any thing,
that shall be required. W
t
all they offer to
goe themselves in person w
t
e forces, to leave
their wives and children behind for pledges, and
to marche
e formost in
e
entring
e towne.
Likewise if her Ma
tie
for her more satisfaction,
and to be better informed of
e true site of
e
forsaid portes, passages, advenues, and other necessary
places, shall determine to send some fitte person
fol.267v
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
to take a praecise viewe of all
e towne, they will
also take order, for some other of their owne appoin-
tment, to goe w
t
him, and to shewe him all that
hath bin signified, and w
at
soever els is pertinent.
In
e meane season, for
e better understanding of
his plotte, I caused him to pourtray
e towne in a
rude forme, and to adde those notes, and expla-
nation unto it, whiche I will send with this letter
to yo
r
L. Considering that
e states of these contreis, by reason of their shipping, mariners,
and souldiers, of w
ch
they have sufficient, and al-
waies in a readines, are better furnished of meanes,
to bring this mater to passe, then her Ma
tie
I urged
him to tell me, w
at
had moved him herein, to
seeke sooner to her Ma
tie
then to
e contrey. Whereto
he answeared that for
Holland
, and
Zeland
,
whome
e rest of the Provinces are accustomed to
followe, they have maliced
e good estate of
Flanders
, and if any towne of that Province
should falle into their handes, they will ether neg-
lect
e custody of it, as they did of
Sluis
, or lett
it come to povertie and ruine, as
e towne of
Ostend, and suffer none of them, at no time, to
enjoy any trafficke. For these and other like
causes, although her Ma
tie
should reject his
motion, he hath no disposition to deale w
t
e states
but will rather attend, till some convenience
be offered to effect it otherwise. Howe
muche her Ma
tie
may be steeded, by having that
place, it is easie enough for any, to conjecture in
generall. But I am certified in particular,
at
the villages adjoining, are 300 at
e lest, whiche
fol.268r
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
:
are all in contribution, and doe not yeld so
litle rent, by common estimation, as 2000
li
ster
l
by
e moneth. But for
e towne it self, whether
this be
e way to put
e Enemie from it, whiche
hath bin signified unto me, and whether it
come her Ma
tie
to passe, to undertake it presently,
I knowe yo
r
L. can best, and soonest resolve.
For whiche it may please yow, to consider upon it,
and if yow finde it so muche worthe, to acquaint
her Hig
nes
w
t
my letter. Also that whiche is
desired, and I have promised, is an answear
to
e party of her Hig
nes
intention, whiche I trust
yo
r
L. will vouchesafe, to returne with the
soonest.
And so for this present, I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. Au
g
23 A
o
90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden,
Tho. Bodley
